key_insight: DREX dynamically regroup s in-flight tokens/requests so that Early-Exit LLMs can exit some samples early without stalling the whole batch, preserving throughput while recovering the per-token latency and quality benefits of early exits.
problem_solved: Conventional batching assumes all requests in a batch progress synchronously, which prevents effective use of Early-Exit models — either wasting computation by holding fast examples, or lowering output quality by forcing premature exits.
method: Run-time dynamic rebatching: continuously form new micro-batches from requests that are ready to proceed or exit, rather than treating the original batch as a fixed unit.
Latency–quality-aware scheduler: decide when to rebatch vs. wait using a policy that trades small scheduling overheads for large computation savings and preserved output quality.
Efficient execution primitives: token-level packing and async GPU execution to amortize rebatching overhead and keep hardware utilization high.
impact: Practitioners can deploy Early-Exit LLMs with much better real-world latency and compute efficiency without sacrificing accuracy, enabling cost-effective, low-latency inference on production hardware.
visual_elements: Layer pipeline diagram showing tokens flowing through model layers with conditional early exits and arrows illustrating dynamic regrouping into new micro-batches.
Latency vs. throughput bar/line chart comparing static batching, forced-exit baseline, and DREX (showing lower per-token latency with retained throughput).
Scheduler timeline / swimlane that visualizes arrival times, exit readiness, and dynamic rebatching events across GPUs.
Icon set: GPU utilization gauge, quality/accuracy shield, and stopwatch for latency to quickly convey benefits.
paper_title: Dynamic Rebatching for Efficient Early-Exit Inference with DREX
paper_authors: Xuting Liu, Daniel Alexander, Siva Kesava Reddy Kakarla, Behnaz Arzani, Vincent Liu
